definition: pride goes before a fall (idiom)
proud/arrogant

(after a verb or adjective) one who (is) .../(after a noun) person involved in .../-er/-ist/(used after a number or 後|后[hou4] or 前[qian2] to refer to sth mentioned previously)/(used after a term, to mark a pause before defining the term)/(old) (used at the end of a command)/(old) this
certainly/must/will/necessarily
to defeat/to damage/to lose (to an opponent)/to fail/to wither

sentences.english: More and more people are forgetting the saying, "Pride comes before a fall."
sentences.chinese: 有愈来愈多的人忘记了“骄者必败”这句俗话。

sentences.english: We should always remember the saying. "Pride comes before a fall."
sentences.chinese: 我们应该随时记住这个俗语“骄者必败”。

sentences.english: The teachings of Confucius tell us to be humble.
sentences.chinese: 骄者必败孔子教导我们要谦虚。

sentences.english: You think you are one of the high and mighty, remember pride goes before a fall.
sentences.chinese: 自以为是了不起的人物，别忘了骄者必败。

definition: Men of Zheng fighting over their respective ages (idiom)/a futile quarrel
rooted to the spot (idiom); too terrified to move
to correct in the evening a fault of the morning (idiom)/to quickly amend one's ways
to offend people with unkind remarks (idiom)
to start on virtue but give up (idiom); to fail to carry things through/lack of sticking power/short attention span
to praise sb in his presence
lit. called a king if successful, called a bandit if defeated (idiom)/fig. losers are always in the wrong
pinyin: cheng2 ze2 wei2 wang2 , bai4 ze2 wei2 kou4

definition: to kill a pig as a lesson to the children (idiom); parents must teach by example
lit. light as a goose feather, heavy as Mt Tai (idiom)/fig. of no consequence to one person, a matter of life or death to another
lit. sincerity splits open metal and metal (idiom); if you put your heart to it, you can break up metal and rocks/With a will, you can achieve anything.
pinyin: jing1 cheng2 suo3 jia1 , jin1 shi2 wei4 kai1

definition: to revere the master and his teaching
clumsy in speech/tongue tied
if it's plowing, ask the laborer (idiom); when managing a matter, consult the appropriate specialist
lit. the old horse loves his stable/fig. sb old but reluctant to relinquish their post (idiom)
magnanimous/generous/broad-minded
to call sth a cow or a horse (idiom); it doesn't matter what you call it/Insult me if you want, I don't care what you call me.
